Current commit [7c918f34a8](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/7c918f34a8b2484ef4bae1a296246901c12a5972)
Reference commit [b23a78ef44](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/b23a78ef44c332aef4db22a4183d658554e4e343)

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

This PR/issue depends on:
* leanprover-community/mathlib4#21362
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

Would it be worthy to try to track degree and number of open sets separately?
(I'd say yes: in some parts of AG, it's useful to know that some varieties are defined by equations of degree 2.)

Do you mean "number of polynomials" rather than "number of open sets"? We're tracking the former, not the latter.

Given the shape of the bound (a tower of size depending on both the degree and number of polynomials used to describe the original variety), I doubt it is possible to track both variables independently.
What property is there for `PrimeSpectrum` that makes this true and not for more general topological spaces?

It's the presence of a basis consisting of compact sets whose pairwise intersections are compact too. See https://stacks.math.columbia.edu/tag/0069

Note that the general case is already proved: it's `IsTopologicalBasis.isRetrocompact_iff_isCompact` and we're using it here
Actually, it's equivalent to there being a basis of compact sets and the space being quasi-separated. See #21325.

pullRequest.title: feat: Chevalley's theorem
